Title: A Cluster Randomised Controlled Trial of the Modified Hospital Elder Life Program in Reducing Delirium and Length of Stay in Older Patients Undergoing Abdominal Surgery

Background: Delirium is a common and preventable complication in older patients undergoing abdominal surgery, leading to extended hospital length of stay (LOS).

Methods: This cluster randomised controlled trial was conducted at a 2000-bed urban medical center in Taipei, Taiwan, from August 1, 2009, to October 31, 2012. Participants were older patients (≥65 years) undergoing elective gastrectomy, pancreaticoduodenectomy, or colectomy with an expected LOS longer than 6 days. A total of 377 patients were cluster randomised by room to receive either the modified Hospital Elder Life Program (mHELP) or usual care. The intervention included orienting communication, oral and nutritional assistance, and early mobilization, administered daily by an mHELP nurse. The primary outcome was the presence of delirium, assessed daily using the Confusion Assessment Method by blinded nurses. LOS was also measured.

Results: Of 577 eligible patients, 377 were randomised (197 to mHELP, 180 to control). Delirium occurred in 6.6% of mHELP participants versus 15.1% of controls, with a relative risk of 0.44 (95% CI, 0.23–0.83; P = .008). The median LOS was 12.0 days for mHELP and 14.0 days for controls (P = .04). No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: The mHELP significantly reduced the odds of delirium by 56% and decreased LOS by 2 days in older patients undergoing major abdominal surgery. Trial registration: NCT01045330. Funding: Not specified.
